facts.title: Harper
facts.body: Dogs are not colorblind. They can see blue and yellow.

facts.title: JoJo
facts.body: Human blood pressure goes down when petting a dog. And so does the dog’s.

facts.title: Kida and Milo
facts.body: Dogs curl up in a ball when sleeping to protect their organs—a hold over from their days in the wild, when they were vulnerable to predator attacks

facts.title: Leo
facts.body: Seventy percent of people sign their dog’s name on their holiday cards.

facts.title: Lola
facts.body: Yawning is contagious—even for dogs. Research shows that the sound of a human yawn can trigger one from your dog. And it’s four times as likely to happen when it’s the yawn of a person he knows.

facts.title: Maude
facts.body: A study at UCSD claims that your dog can genuinely get jealous when they see you display affection for another creature.

facts.title: Motley
facts.body: Forty-five percent of U.S. dogs sleep in their owner’s bed

facts.title: Olaf
facts.body: Speaking of sleeping … all dogs dream, but puppies and senior dogs dream more frequently than adult dogs.

facts.title: Poppy
facts.body: Dogs have about 1,700 taste buds. We humans have between 2,000–10,000.

facts.title: Rhubarb
facts.body: Your dog is as smart as a two-year-old child.

facts.title: Simba
facts.body: A recent study shows that dogs are among a small group of animals who show voluntary unselfish kindness towards others without any reward. This is one fact dog lovers have known all along.

facts.title: Sumo
facts.body: Dogs have 18 muscles to move their ears.

facts.title: Themba
facts.body: Dogs’ noses can sense heat/thermal radiation, which explains why blind or deaf dogs can still hunt.

facts.title: Trooper
facts.body: A dog’s nose print is unique, much like a person’s fingerprint

facts.title: Tuna
facts.body: A dog’s sense of smell is legendary, but did you know that his nose has as many as 300 million receptors? In comparison, a human nose has about 5 million
